title: Security Audit
text:
Date: 2026-02-13



Audit status: setup complete
Findings: not yet run in this repo
Report: security_audit_report.json





Working tree files (excluding common binary formats and very large files)
Full git history (all blobs)





Binary formats (images, PDFs, archives, etc.) are not scanned.
Files over 2 MB are skipped to keep the scan fast.
If you need deeper binary scanning, use a specialized tool and update the script accordingly.





Automated scan script at scripts/security_audit.py
Pre-commit hook at .githooks/pre-commit
GitHub Actions workflow at .github/workflows/security_scan.yml




Enable the repo hook path so the pre-commit scan runs locally:

git config core.hooksPath .githooks




This repo includes .github/workflows/publish.yml to deploy the site to GitHub Pages using GitHub Actions.
In GitHub:

Go to Settings > Pages.
Under Build and deployment, select GitHub Actions.
Save the settings.





Protect the main branch:

Require pull request reviews
Require status checks to pass (Security Scan, Publish Site)
Require signed commits
Require linear history

Require signed commits locally:

git config commit.gpgsign true
Use either GPG or SSH signing (GitHub supports both)






Rotate or revoke the credential immediately.
Remove the secret from the repository.
Purge it from history using git filter-repo:

https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo

Force-push the cleaned history and notify collaborators.





Full scan (worktree + history):

python scripts/security_audit.py

Staged-only scan (pre-commit mode):

python scripts/security_audit.py ‚Äìstaged ‚Äìno-history

title: Unit 2: Potato Patch Prep (3 lessons)
text: This short unit links practical work to risk management by preparing the potato patch. Students identify hazards, use tools safely, and complete the prep steps.

title: Unit 2: Potato Patch Prep (3 lessons)
text: This short unit links practical work to risk management by preparing the potato patch. Students identify hazards, use tools safely, and complete the prep steps.

title: Unit 2: Potato Patch Prep (3 lessons)
text:
Lesson structure (3 lessons)








Lesson
Focus
Outcome




Lesson 1
Hazards and safe tool use
Students can name hazards and apply controls.


Lesson 2
Turn over and prep the patch
Soil is loosened and turf is removed.


Lesson 3
Compost, break up soil, level
Patch is composted and ready for planting.

title: Unit 2: Potato Patch Prep (3 lessons)
section: Practical session: Potato patch prep (40 min)
text:
Practical session: Potato patch prep (40 min)
Goal: Turn over and prepare the potato patch for planting by removing grass, loosening soil, and mixing compost.

Group tasks (20 students total)









Group
Students
Task focus
Key actions




Group A
7
Remove top grass
Lift turf, stack it in a designated pile, clear roots.


Group B
7
Turn over soil
Use forks/spades to loosen and flip soil to one spade depth.


Group C
6
Compost and break up soil
Spread compost, break clods, rake level.





Timing (40 min)

0-5 min: Safety briefing, tool allocation, demo of safe spade/fork use.
5-30 min: Group work on tasks.
30-35 min: Rotate quick checks, finish edges, tidy stacks.
35-40 min: Tool clean-up, wash hands, quick reflection.



Tools and materials

Spades (for turf lifting)
Garden forks (for turning soil)
Rakes (for leveling)
Buckets or barrow (for compost)
Gloves (one pair per student)
Water bottle and sunscreen (if required)



Risks and controls







Risk
Control




Blisters or cuts
Gloves required, correct tool grip demo.


Tool injuries (spade/fork)
Spacing rule: arm‚Äôs length plus tool length; tools down when not in use.


Trips on uneven ground
Clear walkways; keep tools flat on ground when resting.


Manual handling strain
Use knees when lifting turf; share heavy loads.


Sun exposure
Hats, sunscreen, water breaks.





Extra process ideas

Mark the patch boundary with string before starting.
Assign a student as timekeeper for mid-lesson check-in.
Photograph before/after for reflection or mapping updates.

title: Mission 4: Environmental Observation
text: Your mission is to observe and document environmental conditions on the farm. These observations help us understand ecosystem health and biodiversity.

title: Mission 4: Environmental Observation
text: Your mission is to observe and document environmental conditions on the farm. These observations help us understand ecosystem health and biodiversity.

title: Mission 4: Environmental Observation
text:
The Stream Study
Water quality and flow are indicators of ecosystem health:

Observe and Record:
Visual Assessment: - [ ] Look: Is the water clear or murky? Is it flowing fast or slow? - [ ] Check water level - high, normal, or low? - [ ] Look for signs of erosion along banks - [ ] Note any debris or pollution - [ ] Observe aquatic life (insects, fish, etc.)
Auditory Assessment: - [ ] Listen: Can you hear the water? Describe the sound - [ ] Can you identify any bird calls nearby? - [ ] What other sounds do you notice in this area? - [ ] Is it quieter or noisier than other parts of the farm?
Sensory Assessment: - [ ] Smell & Feel: Does the air smell damp? - [ ] Is it cooler here than in the open paddock? - [ ] Is there a breeze? From which direction? - [ ] How does the vegetation differ near the stream?
Water Quality Indicators: - Clear water = healthy stream - Murky water = recent rain, erosion, or pollution - Presence of aquatic insects = good water quality - Variety of bird species = healthy ecosystem
Recording Tips: - Take photos at the same spot each visit - Note the date, time, and weather conditions - Compare your observations to previous visits - Report any concerns (pollution, dead fish, etc.)

title: Mission 4: Environmental Observation
text:
Bee Watch
Monitor bee activity to understand colony health:

The Observation Protocol:
Safety First: - [ ] Stand to the side of the hive (stay out of the flight path!) - [ ] Maintain at least 2 meters distance - [ ] Move slowly and calmly - [ ] Don‚Äôt wear strong perfumes or dark colors - [ ] Never tap or disturb the hive
The Minute Count: - [ ] Position yourself safely to the side of the entrance - [ ] Set a timer for 60 seconds - [ ] Count: How many bees leave the hive in 60 seconds? - [ ] Count: How many bees return in the same period? - [ ] Note the weather conditions during your count - [ ] Record your observations for next week‚Äôs comparison
What the Numbers Mean: - High activity (50+ bees/minute) = healthy, active colony - Medium activity (20-50 bees/minute) = normal for cooler weather - Low activity (<20 bees/minute) = cold weather or potential problem - More leaving than returning = foraging mission - More returning than leaving = bringing in resources
Additional Observations: - [ ] Are bees carrying pollen? (Look for yellow/orange on legs) - [ ] Do bees appear healthy and active? - [ ] Are there dead bees around the entrance? - [ ] Is the entrance clear of debris? - [ ] Any unusual sounds from inside?

title: Mission 4: Environmental Observation
text:
General Environmental Notes
Observe the bigger picture:

Note the weather: temperature, wind, cloud cover
What wildlife did you see today? (birds, insects, mammals)
Are any plants flowering?
Any seasonal changes observed?
Overall impression of farm ecosystem health

title: Mission 4: Environmental Observation
text:
Completion
Once all observations are recorded: - [ ] Write up your findings in the observation log - [ ] Date and sign your entry - [ ] Compare with previous observations - [ ] Report any urgent concerns to farm supervisor - [ ] Discuss interesting findings with classmates
Mission Status: Complete! üêùüèûÔ∏è

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text: Your mission is to maintain the health and productivity of our garden beds, berry house, and seedlings. Complete these tasks to ensure our crops thrive.

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text: Your mission is to maintain the health and productivity of our garden beds, berry house, and seedlings. Complete these tasks to ensure our crops thrive.

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text:
The Watering Run
Proper watering is essential for plant health:

Use the blue bin supply to fill watering cans
Deliver at least 2 full cans per raised bed
Bonus: Water the herb boxes by the barn
Water at the base of plants, avoiding leaves when possible
Check soil moisture before watering - should be damp but not soggy

Watering Tips: - Water in early morning or late afternoon to minimize evaporation - Different plants need different amounts - observe and adjust - Seedlings need gentle watering to avoid displacement

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text:
Weed & Tend
Keep garden beds healthy and productive:

Collect gloves, a fork, and a wheelbarrow
Identify and remove weeds from the vegetable and ‚Äúno-dig‚Äù beds
Gently turn the topsoil to aerate it for new growth
Remove any dead or diseased plant material
Check plants for pests or disease

Weeding Guidance: - Pull weeds from the root to prevent regrowth - Be careful not to disturb crop roots - Add weeds to compost pile (if not seeding)

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text:
The Berry House Mission
Maintain the berry house for optimal fruit production:

Weed around the base of the berry plants
Apply a fresh layer of wood chips to suppress future weeds and hold moisture
Check berry plants for fruit development
Remove any dead canes or leaves
Ensure plants are properly supported

Berry Care Notes: - Wood chip mulch helps retain moisture - Keep 5cm space between mulch and plant stems - Monitor for signs of disease or pest damage

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text:
Planting & Propagation
Care for the next generation of plants:

Check the seed raising tray in the tunnel house
Use a spray bottle to dampen the soil of any emerging seedlings
Remove any failed seedlings
Transplant any seedlings ready for the next stage
Label all trays clearly

Seedling Care: - Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged - Provide adequate light and ventilation - Watch for signs of damping off disease

title: Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
text:
Completion
Once all tasks are completed: - [ ] Clean and return all tools to storage - [ ] Empty and store watering cans properly - [ ] Record observations in the garden log - [ ] Note any issues for follow-up
Mission Status: Complete! üå±ü´ê

title: Farm Missions
text:
Farm Missions are regular maintenance and care tasks that anyone can undertake once they have read and followed the instructions on each mission ticklist. Each mission focuses on a specific area of farm management and can be completed independently.
These missions help ensure the ongoing health and productivity of our urban farm while providing hands-on learning opportunities for students.

title: Farm Missions
text:
Farm Missions are regular maintenance and care tasks that anyone can undertake once they have read and followed the instructions on each mission ticklist. Each mission focuses on a specific area of farm management and can be completed independently.
These missions help ensure the ongoing health and productivity of our urban farm while providing hands-on learning opportunities for students.

title: Farm Missions
text:
Available Missions

Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
Focus: Chickens and paddock animals
Ensure the health and wellbeing of our farm animals through proper feeding, watering, and observation.

Check and refill water containers
Provide feed and treats
Observe animal health and behavior
Maintain clean bedding

Go to Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation



Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
Focus: Vegetables, berries, and seedlings
Maintain the health and productivity of our garden beds, berry house, and young plants.

Water raised beds and herb boxes
Weed and aerate garden beds
Maintain berry house mulching
Care for seedlings in tunnel house

Go to Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance



Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
Focus: Native plantings and invasive species control
Protect and maintain the farm‚Äôs restoration areas through weed control and tree monitoring.

Remove invasive gorse
Check young tree health
Maintain tree guards and stakes
Monitor restoration progress

Go to Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health



Mission 4: Environmental Observation
Focus: Ecosystem monitoring and biodiversity
Observe and document environmental conditions to understand ecosystem health.

Study stream water quality and flow
Monitor bee hive activity
Record wildlife observations
Track seasonal changes

Go to Mission 4: Environmental Observation



Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
Focus: Workspace maintenance and tool care
Maintain an organized, safe, and efficient farm workspace.

Tidy barn and shed areas
Organize wood pile and pots
Clean and maintain tools
Conduct security checks

Go to Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory

title: Farm Missions
text:
How to Complete a Mission

Read the entire mission before starting any tasks
Gather required equipment as listed in the mission
Follow safety guidelines specific to each mission
Complete tasks systematically using the ticklist
Record your observations in the farm log
Report any issues to the farm supervisor
Clean up and secure tools and areas when finished

title: Farm Missions
text:
Mission Philosophy

‚ÄúLeave the farm better than you found it‚Äù

Each mission is designed to be: - Self-contained: All instructions included - Achievable: Completable in a reasonable timeframe - Educational: Learning through practical application - Valuable: Contributing to real farm management - Safe: Clear safety guidelines included

title: Farm Missions
text:
Ready to Begin?
Choose a mission above and start contributing to our urban farm ecosystem. Remember: careful observation and attention to detail make the best farm stewards! üåæ

title: Applied Mathematics: Farm Units
text: This section contains two short units of applied mathematics on the school farm. The mapping unit comes first, followed by a short, practical unit on the potato patch and hazard management.

title: Applied Mathematics: Farm Units
text: This section contains two short units of applied mathematics on the school farm. The mapping unit comes first, followed by a short, practical unit on the potato patch and hazard management.

title: Applied Mathematics: Farm Units
section: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
Focus on mapping the farm, measuring areas and distances, and producing a final map for the workbook.

What you‚Äôll do

Build layers for existing and proposed features.
Measure paddocks and distances.
Export a clean PDF map for your workbook.
Go to: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm

title: Applied Mathematics: Farm Units
text:
Unit 2: Potato Patch Prep (3 lessons)
Focus on hazards, tool safety, and practical preparation of the potato patch.
What you‚Äôll do

Identify hazards and agree on controls.
Turn over soil and remove turf.
Compost and level the patch for planting.
Go to: Unit 2: Potato Patch Prep

title: Applied Mathematics: Farm Units
text:
Farm Operations

Farm Missions
Regular maintenance and care tasks that anyone can undertake. Each mission focuses on a specific area of farm management with detailed instructions and ticklists.
Available Missions:

Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
Mission 2: Garden & Berry House Maintenance
Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
Mission 4: Environmental Observation
Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
Go to: Farm Missions Overview




Friday Close-Down Checklist
A quick final check for Friday afternoon to ensure the farm is secure, clean, and ready for the weekend.
What you‚Äôll do

Verify all animals have weekend supplies
Confirm tools and equipment are secured
Check gates, doors, and utilities
Ensure the farm is ready for Monday
Go to: Friday Close-Down Checklist

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Complete the following sets to consolidate your understanding of key mathematical terms. Read the Worked Example carefully before starting the questions.










Term
Definition
Picture/Example




BEDMAS
The order of operations used to solve equations.
Brackets, Exponents, Division, Multiplication, Addition, Subtraction.


Integers
All whole numbers, including positive, negative, and zero.
\(... -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 ...\)


Multiple
The result of multiplying a number by an integer.
Multiples of 5: \(5, 10, 15, 20...\)


Factor
A number that divides into another number exactly (without a remainder).
Factors of 10: \(1, 2, 5, 10\).


Power
The product of multiplying a number by itself several times.
\(2^3\) (which is \(2 \times 2 \times 2 = 8\)).


Exponent
The small number written above a base that tells you how many times to use the base in a multiplication.
In \(5^2\), the 2 is the exponent.


Index
Another name for an exponent or power. (The plural is ‚ÄúIndices‚Äù).
\(x^4\) ‚Äî the 4 is the index.


Square root
A number that, when multiplied by itself, gives the original number.
\(\sqrt{25} = 5\) (because \(5 \times 5 = 25\)).


Numerator
The top number in a fraction. It shows how many parts you have.
In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the 3 is the numerator.


Denominator
The bottom number in a fraction. It shows how many equal parts the whole is divided into.
In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the 4 is the denominator.


Mixed fraction
A number consisting of an integer and a proper fraction.
\(2\frac{1}{2}\)


Improper fraction
A fraction where the numerator is larger than (or equal to) the denominator.
\(\frac{5}{2}\)


Equivalent fraction
Fractions that look different but have the same value.
\(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{4}{8}\)


Place value
The value of a digit based on its position in a number.
In \(3\mathbf{4}2\), the 4 is in the ‚Äòtens‚Äô place (value = 40).


Decimal place
The position of a digit to the right of a decimal point.
In \(3.1\mathbf{4}\), the 4 is in the second decimal place (hundredths).


Scientific Notation
A way of writing very large or very small numbers using a number between 1 and 10 multiplied by a power of 10.
\(3 \times 10^8\)


Recurring Decimal
A decimal number that has digits that repeat forever.
\(0.333...\) or \(0.\dot{3}\)







Concept: A Decimal place refers to the position of a digit to the right of the decimal point.


Question: How many decimal places are in the number \(3.14\)? Answer: There are two digits after the point (1 and 4), so there are 2 decimal places.




How many decimal places are in the number \(4.5\)?
How many decimal places are in the number \(10.123\)?
Identify the digit in the first decimal place in \(0.75\).
Identify the digit in the second decimal place in \(12.89\).
Round \(4.56\) to one decimal place.
Round \(3.333\) to two decimal places.
Which number has more decimal places: \(5.1\) or \(5.01\)?
Write the number \(\frac{1}{2}\) as a number with one decimal place.
Write the number \(\frac{1}{4}\) as a number with two decimal places.
If you add \(1.2\) and \(0.05\), how many decimal places will the answer have?






Concept: Integers are whole numbers. They can be positive, negative, or zero. When ordering them, remember that larger negative numbers are ‚Äúcolder‚Äù (further to the left on the number line).


Question: Arrange the following integers from smallest to largest: \(3, -5, 0, -2, 7\) Answer: \(-5, -2, 0, 3, 7\)




List the integers in this set: \(\{ 4.5, -2, 10, \frac{1}{2}, 0 \}\)
Arrange these integers from smallest to largest: \(-7, 4, -1, 0, 9\)
Arrange these integers from smallest to largest: \(-10, -15, 2, -2, 5\)
Write the integer that is 5 less than 2.
Write the integer that is 3 more than -5.
Which integer represents a colder temperature: \(-4^\circ\text{C}\) or \(-12^\circ\text{C}\)?
Calculate the new integer: \(5 - 8\)
Calculate the new integer: \(-3 + 7\)
Insert \(<\) or \(>\) between these integers: \(-5\) ___ \(-2\)
Insert \(<\) or \(>\) between these integers: \(0\) ___ \(-8\)






Concept: The Place value of a digit tells you its value based on its position (e.g., Hundreds, Tens, Units).


Question: What is the place value of the digit 6 in the number \(462\)? Answer: The 6 is in the Tens column. Its place value is 60.




What is the place value of the 7 in \(725\)?
What is the place value of the 3 in \(139\)?
What is the place value of the 1 in \(1,200\)?
Which digit has a place value of 40 in \(445\)?
Write the number: Five hundreds, zero tens, and six units.
What is the place value of the 9 in \(90\)?
In the number \(3,456\), which digit is in the thousands place?
Multiply \(45\) by \(10\). How does the place value of the 4 change?
Divide \(320\) by \(10\).
How many tens are there in the number \(140\)?






Concept: Factors are Few. They are whole numbers that fit exactly inside another number (no remainder).


Question: List all factors of 12. Answer: \(1 \times 12 = 12\), \(2 \times 6 = 12\), \(3 \times 4 = 12\). Factors: \(1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12\)




List all factors of 6.
List all factors of 10.
List all factors of 15.
List all factors of 20.
Is 5 a factor of 25?
Is 4 a factor of 14?
What is the largest factor of 8 (excluding 8 itself)?
True or False: 1 is a factor of every number.
Find a number that has exactly two factors (a prime number) between 1 and 10.
Circle the factors of 18 in this list: \(2, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10\).






Concept: Multiples are Many. They are the result of multiplying a number by an integer. They go up like times tables.


Question: List the first four multiples of 5. Answer: \(5 \times 1 = 5\), \(5 \times 2 = 10\), \(5 \times 3 = 15\), \(5 \times 4 = 20\). Multiples: \(5, 10, 15, 20\)




List the first four multiples of 2.
List the first four multiples of 3.
List the first four multiples of 10.
What is the 5th multiple of 4?
Is 24 a multiple of 6?
Is 25 a multiple of 4?
List a common multiple of 2 and 3.
True or False: Multiples can be smaller than the original number.
What is the multiple of 7 that comes after 21?
Circle the multiples of 8 in this list: \(4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24\).






Concept: An Exponent (or Index) tells you how many times to multiply the base by itself to create a Power.


Question: Identify the exponent in \(4^3\) and calculate the power. Answer: The exponent (or index) is 3. Expanded: \(4 \times 4 \times 4 = 64\).




Write \(2^3\) in expanded form. What is the exponent?
Write \(5 \times 5\) as a power using an index.
Calculate the value of the power \(3^2\).
What is the index in the expression \(y^4\)?
Calculate the value of \(10^2\).
Calculate the value of \(1^5\).
In the expression \(x^6\), what is the base and what is the exponent?
Write ‚Äúsix to the power of two‚Äù in math notation.
Calculate \(5^2 + 2^2\).
If the index is 1, what does the number equal?






Concept: The Square root asks ‚ÄúWhich number times itself equals this?‚Äù It is the opposite of squaring a number.


Question: Find the square root of 49 (\(\sqrt{49}\)). Answer: Since \(7 \times 7 = 49\), the square root is 7.




Find the square root of 9.
Find the square root of 16.
Find the square root of 25.
Find the square root of 64.
Find the square root of 81.
Find the square root of 100.
Find the square root of 1.
Find the square root of 144.
True or False: The square root of 36 is 18.
Calculate \(\sqrt{4} + \sqrt{9}\).






Concept: BEDMAS is the order of operations: Brackets, Exponents, Division/Multiplication, Addition/Subtraction.


Question: Use BEDMAS to solve \(3 + 4 \times 2\). Answer: Multiplication first (\(4 \times 2 = 8\)). Then Addition (\(3 + 8 = 11\)). Answer: 11.




Using BEDMAS, solve: \(2 + 3 \times 4\)
Using BEDMAS, solve: \(10 - 2 \times 3\)
Solve: \((5 + 5) \times 2\)
Solve: \(20 \div 2 + 3\)
Solve: \(3 \times 3 + 2 \times 4\)
Solve: \(10 - 3^2\)
Solve: \(2 \times (10 - 5)\)
Solve: \(4 + 4 \div 4\)
Solve: \(5^2 - 10\)
Solve: \((2 + 3)^2\)






Concept: Numerator is North (Up). Denominator is Down.


Question: Identify the numerator and denominator in \(\frac{3}{5}\). Answer: Numerator = 3, Denominator = 5.




What is the numerator in \(\frac{1}{2}\)?
What is the denominator in \(\frac{4}{9}\)?
Which number is the denominator in \(\frac{7}{8}\)?
Which number is the numerator in \(\frac{2}{3}\)?
Write a fraction with numerator 2 and denominator 3.
Write the fraction: Three quarters. Identify the denominator.
In \(\frac{1}{4}\), does the denominator tell you the number of parts shaded or the total parts?
If the denominator is 10 and the numerator is 7, write the fraction.
What fraction of a shape is shaded if 2 out of 5 pieces are colored?
True or False: The denominator can never be 0.






Concept: An Improper fraction is ‚Äútop-heavy‚Äù. A Mixed fraction has a whole number part and a fraction part.


Question: Convert the improper fraction \(\frac{5}{2}\) to a mixed fraction. Answer: How many 2s go into 5? (2 whole times, remainder 1). Answer: \(2\frac{1}{2}\).




Is \(\frac{4}{3}\) an improper fraction or a mixed fraction?
Is \(1\frac{1}{2}\) an improper fraction or a mixed fraction?
Convert \(\frac{3}{2}\) to a mixed fraction.
Convert \(\frac{5}{3}\) to a mixed fraction.
Convert \(\frac{7}{4}\) to a mixed fraction.
Convert the mixed fraction \(1\frac{1}{4}\) to an improper fraction.
Convert the mixed fraction \(2\frac{1}{2}\) to an improper fraction.
Which is larger: the improper fraction \(\frac{3}{2}\) or the number \(1\)?
Write ‚Äútwo and a half‚Äù as a mixed fraction.
Write ‚Äúthree halves‚Äù as an improper fraction.






Concept: Equivalent fractions have the same value but different numbers. Multiply or divide the top and bottom by the same number.


Question: Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{8}\) Answer: To get from 2 to 8, we multiply by 4. So we multiply the top by 4 as well. \(1 \times 4 = 4\). Answer: \(\frac{4}{8}\).




Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{4}\)
Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{1}{3} = \frac{?}{6}\)
Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{2}{5} = \frac{4}{?}\)
Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{3}{4} = \frac{?}{8}\)
Simplify \(\frac{2}{4}\) to find the simplest equivalent fraction.
Simplify \(\frac{5}{10}\) to find the simplest equivalent fraction.
Find an equivalent fraction for \(\frac{6}{8}\) by dividing top and bottom by 2.
Are \(\frac{1}{2}\) and \(\frac{5}{10}\) equivalent fractions?
Are \(\frac{2}{3}\) and \(\frac{4}{5}\) equivalent fractions?
Fill in the blank: \(\frac{10}{20} = \frac{1}{?}\)






Concept: Scientific Notation is a way to write numbers as \(a \times 10^n\), where \(1 \le a < 10\) and \(n\) is an integer.


Question: Write 4500 in scientific notation. Answer: Move the decimal point to get a number between 1 and 10 (4.5). Count how many places it moved (3 places). Answer: \(4.5 \times 10^3\).




Write 3000 in scientific notation.
Write 2,500,000 in scientific notation.
Write \(5 \times 10^2\) as a standard number.
Write \(1.2 \times 10^3\) as a standard number.
In \(3.4 \times 10^5\), which number is the base?
In \(3.4 \times 10^5\), which number is the exponent?
Write 0.004 in scientific notation (remember negative exponents for small numbers).
Write \(2 \times 10^{-2}\) as a decimal.
Which is larger: \(1 \times 10^4\) or \(9 \times 10^3\)?
True or False: In scientific notation, the first number must be between 1 and 10.






Concept: A Recurring decimal has a digit (or group of digits) that repeats forever. We use a dot (or a bar) over the repeating part.


Question: Write the fraction \(\frac{1}{3}\) as a recurring decimal. Answer: \(1 \div 3 = 0.3333...\) which is written as \(0.\dot{3}\).




What does the dot in \(0.\dot{5}\) mean?
Write \(0.666...\) using dot notation.
Write the fraction \(\frac{2}{3}\) as a recurring decimal.
Is \(0.5\) a recurring decimal?
Write \(0.\dot{1}\) as a decimal with three digits showing.
Convert \(\frac{1}{9}\) to a recurring decimal (\(1 \div 9\)).
True or False: \(0.\dot{9}\) is equal to 1.
Which notation represents \(0.121212...\)? (A) \(0.\dot{1}\dot{2}\) or (B) \(0.1\dot{2}\)?
Does \(\frac{1}{2}\) result in a recurring decimal?
Write the number that is exactly double \(0.\dot{3}\).

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Term
Definition
Picture/Example




BEDMAS
The order of operations used to solve equations.
Brackets, Exponents, Division, Multiplication, Addition, Subtraction.


Integers
All whole numbers, including positive, negative, and zero.
\(... -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 ...\)


Multiple
The result of multiplying a number by an integer.
Multiples of 5: \(5, 10, 15, 20...\)


Factor
A number that divides into another number exactly (without a remainder).
Factors of 10: \(1, 2, 5, 10\).


Power
The product of multiplying a number by itself several times.
\(2^3\) (which is \(2 \times 2 \times 2 = 8\)).


Exponent
The small number written above a base that tells you how many times to use the base in a multiplication.
In \(5^2\), the 2 is the exponent.


Index
Another name for an exponent or power. (The plural is ‚ÄúIndices‚Äù).
\(x^4\) ‚Äî the 4 is the index.


Square root
A number that, when multiplied by itself, gives the original number.
\(\sqrt{25} = 5\) (because \(5 \times 5 = 25\)).


Numerator
The top number in a fraction. It shows how many parts you have.
In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the 3 is the numerator.


Denominator
The bottom number in a fraction. It shows how many equal parts the whole is divided into.
In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the 4 is the denominator.


Mixed fraction
A number consisting of an integer and a proper fraction.
\(2\frac{1}{2}\)


Improper fraction
A fraction where the numerator is larger than (or equal to) the denominator.
\(\frac{5}{2}\)


Equivalent fraction
Fractions that look different but have the same value.
\(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{4}{8}\)


Place value
The value of a digit based on its position in a number.
In \(3\mathbf{4}2\), the 4 is in the ‚Äòtens‚Äô place (value = 40).


Decimal place
The position of a digit to the right of a decimal point.
In \(3.1\mathbf{4}\), the 4 is in the second decimal place (hundredths).


Scientific Notation
A way of writing very large or very small numbers using a number between 1 and 10 multiplied by a power of 10.
\(3 \times 10^8\)


Recurring Decimal
A decimal number that has digits that repeat forever.
\(0.333...\) or \(0.\dot{3}\)

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: A Decimal place refers to the position of a digit to the right of the decimal point.


Question: How many decimal places are in the number \(3.14\)? Answer: There are two digits after the point (1 and 4), so there are 2 decimal places.




How many decimal places are in the number \(4.5\)?
How many decimal places are in the number \(10.123\)?
Identify the digit in the first decimal place in \(0.75\).
Identify the digit in the second decimal place in \(12.89\).
Round \(4.56\) to one decimal place.
Round \(3.333\) to two decimal places.
Which number has more decimal places: \(5.1\) or \(5.01\)?
Write the number \(\frac{1}{2}\) as a number with one decimal place.
Write the number \(\frac{1}{4}\) as a number with two decimal places.
If you add \(1.2\) and \(0.05\), how many decimal places will the answer have?

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: Integers are whole numbers. They can be positive, negative, or zero. When ordering them, remember that larger negative numbers are ‚Äúcolder‚Äù (further to the left on the number line).


Question: Arrange the following integers from smallest to largest: \(3, -5, 0, -2, 7\) Answer: \(-5, -2, 0, 3, 7\)




List the integers in this set: \(\{ 4.5, -2, 10, \frac{1}{2}, 0 \}\)
Arrange these integers from smallest to largest: \(-7, 4, -1, 0, 9\)
Arrange these integers from smallest to largest: \(-10, -15, 2, -2, 5\)
Write the integer that is 5 less than 2.
Write the integer that is 3 more than -5.
Which integer represents a colder temperature: \(-4^\circ\text{C}\) or \(-12^\circ\text{C}\)?
Calculate the new integer: \(5 - 8\)
Calculate the new integer: \(-3 + 7\)
Insert \(<\) or \(>\) between these integers: \(-5\) ___ \(-2\)
Insert \(<\) or \(>\) between these integers: \(0\) ___ \(-8\)

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: The Place value of a digit tells you its value based on its position (e.g., Hundreds, Tens, Units).


Question: What is the place value of the digit 6 in the number \(462\)? Answer: The 6 is in the Tens column. Its place value is 60.




What is the place value of the 7 in \(725\)?
What is the place value of the 3 in \(139\)?
What is the place value of the 1 in \(1,200\)?
Which digit has a place value of 40 in \(445\)?
Write the number: Five hundreds, zero tens, and six units.
What is the place value of the 9 in \(90\)?
In the number \(3,456\), which digit is in the thousands place?
Multiply \(45\) by \(10\). How does the place value of the 4 change?
Divide \(320\) by \(10\).
How many tens are there in the number \(140\)?

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: Factors are Few. They are whole numbers that fit exactly inside another number (no remainder).


Question: List all factors of 12. Answer: \(1 \times 12 = 12\), \(2 \times 6 = 12\), \(3 \times 4 = 12\). Factors: \(1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12\)




List all factors of 6.
List all factors of 10.
List all factors of 15.
List all factors of 20.
Is 5 a factor of 25?
Is 4 a factor of 14?
What is the largest factor of 8 (excluding 8 itself)?
True or False: 1 is a factor of every number.
Find a number that has exactly two factors (a prime number) between 1 and 10.
Circle the factors of 18 in this list: \(2, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10\).

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: Multiples are Many. They are the result of multiplying a number by an integer. They go up like times tables.


Question: List the first four multiples of 5. Answer: \(5 \times 1 = 5\), \(5 \times 2 = 10\), \(5 \times 3 = 15\), \(5 \times 4 = 20\). Multiples: \(5, 10, 15, 20\)




List the first four multiples of 2.
List the first four multiples of 3.
List the first four multiples of 10.
What is the 5th multiple of 4?
Is 24 a multiple of 6?
Is 25 a multiple of 4?
List a common multiple of 2 and 3.
True or False: Multiples can be smaller than the original number.
What is the multiple of 7 that comes after 21?
Circle the multiples of 8 in this list: \(4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24\).

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: An Exponent (or Index) tells you how many times to multiply the base by itself to create a Power.


Question: Identify the exponent in \(4^3\) and calculate the power. Answer: The exponent (or index) is 3. Expanded: \(4 \times 4 \times 4 = 64\).




Write \(2^3\) in expanded form. What is the exponent?
Write \(5 \times 5\) as a power using an index.
Calculate the value of the power \(3^2\).
What is the index in the expression \(y^4\)?
Calculate the value of \(10^2\).
Calculate the value of \(1^5\).
In the expression \(x^6\), what is the base and what is the exponent?
Write ‚Äúsix to the power of two‚Äù in math notation.
Calculate \(5^2 + 2^2\).
If the index is 1, what does the number equal?

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: The Square root asks ‚ÄúWhich number times itself equals this?‚Äù It is the opposite of squaring a number.


Question: Find the square root of 49 (\(\sqrt{49}\)). Answer: Since \(7 \times 7 = 49\), the square root is 7.




Find the square root of 9.
Find the square root of 16.
Find the square root of 25.
Find the square root of 64.
Find the square root of 81.
Find the square root of 100.
Find the square root of 1.
Find the square root of 144.
True or False: The square root of 36 is 18.
Calculate \(\sqrt{4} + \sqrt{9}\).

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: BEDMAS is the order of operations: Brackets, Exponents, Division/Multiplication, Addition/Subtraction.


Question: Use BEDMAS to solve \(3 + 4 \times 2\). Answer: Multiplication first (\(4 \times 2 = 8\)). Then Addition (\(3 + 8 = 11\)). Answer: 11.




Using BEDMAS, solve: \(2 + 3 \times 4\)
Using BEDMAS, solve: \(10 - 2 \times 3\)
Solve: \((5 + 5) \times 2\)
Solve: \(20 \div 2 + 3\)
Solve: \(3 \times 3 + 2 \times 4\)
Solve: \(10 - 3^2\)
Solve: \(2 \times (10 - 5)\)
Solve: \(4 + 4 \div 4\)
Solve: \(5^2 - 10\)
Solve: \((2 + 3)^2\)

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: Numerator is North (Up). Denominator is Down.


Question: Identify the numerator and denominator in \(\frac{3}{5}\). Answer: Numerator = 3, Denominator = 5.




What is the numerator in \(\frac{1}{2}\)?
What is the denominator in \(\frac{4}{9}\)?
Which number is the denominator in \(\frac{7}{8}\)?
Which number is the numerator in \(\frac{2}{3}\)?
Write a fraction with numerator 2 and denominator 3.
Write the fraction: Three quarters. Identify the denominator.
In \(\frac{1}{4}\), does the denominator tell you the number of parts shaded or the total parts?
If the denominator is 10 and the numerator is 7, write the fraction.
What fraction of a shape is shaded if 2 out of 5 pieces are colored?
True or False: The denominator can never be 0.

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: An Improper fraction is ‚Äútop-heavy‚Äù. A Mixed fraction has a whole number part and a fraction part.


Question: Convert the improper fraction \(\frac{5}{2}\) to a mixed fraction. Answer: How many 2s go into 5? (2 whole times, remainder 1). Answer: \(2\frac{1}{2}\).




Is \(\frac{4}{3}\) an improper fraction or a mixed fraction?
Is \(1\frac{1}{2}\) an improper fraction or a mixed fraction?
Convert \(\frac{3}{2}\) to a mixed fraction.
Convert \(\frac{5}{3}\) to a mixed fraction.
Convert \(\frac{7}{4}\) to a mixed fraction.
Convert the mixed fraction \(1\frac{1}{4}\) to an improper fraction.
Convert the mixed fraction \(2\frac{1}{2}\) to an improper fraction.
Which is larger: the improper fraction \(\frac{3}{2}\) or the number \(1\)?
Write ‚Äútwo and a half‚Äù as a mixed fraction.
Write ‚Äúthree halves‚Äù as an improper fraction.

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: Equivalent fractions have the same value but different numbers. Multiply or divide the top and bottom by the same number.


Question: Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{8}\) Answer: To get from 2 to 8, we multiply by 4. So we multiply the top by 4 as well. \(1 \times 4 = 4\). Answer: \(\frac{4}{8}\).




Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{4}\)
Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{1}{3} = \frac{?}{6}\)
Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{2}{5} = \frac{4}{?}\)
Find the equivalent fraction: \(\frac{3}{4} = \frac{?}{8}\)
Simplify \(\frac{2}{4}\) to find the simplest equivalent fraction.
Simplify \(\frac{5}{10}\) to find the simplest equivalent fraction.
Find an equivalent fraction for \(\frac{6}{8}\) by dividing top and bottom by 2.
Are \(\frac{1}{2}\) and \(\frac{5}{10}\) equivalent fractions?
Are \(\frac{2}{3}\) and \(\frac{4}{5}\) equivalent fractions?
Fill in the blank: \(\frac{10}{20} = \frac{1}{?}\)

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: Scientific Notation is a way to write numbers as \(a \times 10^n\), where \(1 \le a < 10\) and \(n\) is an integer.


Question: Write 4500 in scientific notation. Answer: Move the decimal point to get a number between 1 and 10 (4.5). Count how many places it moved (3 places). Answer: \(4.5 \times 10^3\).




Write 3000 in scientific notation.
Write 2,500,000 in scientific notation.
Write \(5 \times 10^2\) as a standard number.
Write \(1.2 \times 10^3\) as a standard number.
In \(3.4 \times 10^5\), which number is the base?
In \(3.4 \times 10^5\), which number is the exponent?
Write 0.004 in scientific notation (remember negative exponents for small numbers).
Write \(2 \times 10^{-2}\) as a decimal.
Which is larger: \(1 \times 10^4\) or \(9 \times 10^3\)?
True or False: In scientific notation, the first number must be between 1 and 10.

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Concept: A Recurring decimal has a digit (or group of digits) that repeats forever. We use a dot (or a bar) over the repeating part.


Question: Write the fraction \(\frac{1}{3}\) as a recurring decimal. Answer: \(1 \div 3 = 0.3333...\) which is written as \(0.\dot{3}\).




What does the dot in \(0.\dot{5}\) mean?
Write \(0.666...\) using dot notation.
Write the fraction \(\frac{2}{3}\) as a recurring decimal.
Is \(0.5\) a recurring decimal?
Write \(0.\dot{1}\) as a decimal with three digits showing.
Convert \(\frac{1}{9}\) to a recurring decimal (\(1 \div 9\)).
True or False: \(0.\dot{9}\) is equal to 1.
Which notation represents \(0.121212...\)? (A) \(0.\dot{1}\dot{2}\) or (B) \(0.1\dot{2}\)?
Does \(\frac{1}{2}\) result in a recurring decimal?
Write the number that is exactly double \(0.\dot{3}\).

title: Farm Mapping Homework
text:
In this homework assignment, you will create a PDF map of the school farm using Google My Maps. Use the class guide in farm/index.Rmd for full instructions. Follow the steps below to complete your task.



Go to https://www.google.co.nz/mymaps and sign in to your Google account.
Create a new map and name it ‚ÄúKaikorai Valley College School Farm‚Äù.
Set up two layers:

Existing for current features (paddocks, dams, fences, buildings, water points).
Proposed for planned work (new planting, new fencing, new water lines).

Add features using the toolbar:

Markers for points (sheds, tanks, troughs, gates).
Lines for fences, tracks, or waterways.
Areas for paddocks or blocks.

Use the Measurement tool (ruler icon) to check at least one distance and one paddock area.
Add these map elements:

Arrow (north) for direction.
Scale to show distances.
Legend that explains your symbols and colors.





Once you have completed your map, export it as a PDF. To do this: 1. Click the three vertical dots next to the map name. 2. Select ‚ÄúPrint map‚Äù and choose the PDF option.



Use these images as a guide while you work.
Layers and map setup

Add markers and lines


Measurement tool

Print map to PDF




After completing your map, please answer the following questions:

What features did you include on your map, and why did you choose them?
How does adding a scale and legend enhance the usability of your map?




This homework aligns with the following New Zealand Curriculum areas:

Geography: Understand how people interact with their environment.
Mathematics: Use measurement and scale in practical contexts.

For more information, visit the New Zealand Curriculum website: New Zealand Curriculum.

Make sure to submit your completed homework by the due date. Happy mapping!

title: Farm Mapping Homework
text:

Set up two layers:

Existing for current features (paddocks, dams, fences, buildings, water points).
Proposed for planned work (new planting, new fencing, new water lines).

Add features using the toolbar:

Markers for points (sheds, tanks, troughs, gates).
Lines for fences, tracks, or waterways.
Areas for paddocks or blocks.

Use the Measurement tool (ruler icon) to check at least one distance and one paddock area.
Add these map elements:

Arrow (north) for direction.
Scale to show distances.
Legend that explains your symbols and colors.





Once you have completed your map, export it as a PDF. To do this: 1. Click the three vertical dots next to the map name. 2. Select ‚ÄúPrint map‚Äù and choose the PDF option.



Use these images as a guide while you work.
Layers and map setup

Add markers and lines


Measurement tool

Print map to PDF

title: Farm Mapping Homework
text:
In this homework assignment, you will create a PDF map of the school farm using Google My Maps. You will learn how to add important features to your map, including an arrow, scale, and legend.




Create Your Map:

Follow the instructions provided in the index.Rmd file to create your farm map using Google My Maps.

Add Features:

Once your map is created, you need to add the following features:

Arrow: Indicate a specific direction on your map.
Scale: Show the scale of your map to help viewers understand distances.
Legend: Create a legend that explains the symbols and colors used on your map.


Export Your Map:

After adding the features, export your map as a PDF. Make sure the arrow, scale, and legend are clearly visible in the exported document.






Explain why it is important to include a scale on your map. How does it help the viewer?
Describe the purpose of a legend in a map. What information should be included in your legend for the school farm map?




This homework aligns with the following areas of the New Zealand Curriculum:

Geography: Understand how to represent geographical information using maps.
Mathematics: Apply measurement concepts in real-world contexts.

For more information, visit the New Zealand Curriculum website: New Zealand Curriculum

Note: Ensure you follow the guidelines and submit your homework by the due date. Happy mapping!

Add Features:

Scale: Show the scale of your map to help viewers understand distances.
Legend: Create a legend that explains the symbols and colors used on your map.

title: Friday Farm Close-Down Checklist
text:
Welcome to the Friday close-down routine! Before leaving for the weekend, complete this final checklist to ensure the farm is secure, clean, and ready for Monday.
Note: If you haven‚Äôt already completed the regular farm missions this week, visit the Farm Missions page to see what needs to be done. The Friday close-down assumes all regular maintenance has been completed.
üìÑ Download: Friday Ticklist PDF - Print this checklist for easy reference on the farm!

title: Friday Farm Close-Down Checklist
text:
Welcome to the Friday close-down routine! Before leaving for the weekend, complete this final checklist to ensure the farm is secure, clean, and ready for Monday.
Note: If you haven‚Äôt already completed the regular farm missions this week, visit the Farm Missions page to see what needs to be done. The Friday close-down assumes all regular maintenance has been completed.
üìÑ Download: Friday Ticklist PDF - Print this checklist for easy reference on the farm!

title: Friday Farm Close-Down Checklist
text:
Final Check
Before you leave for the weekend:

Animal Welfare

All animals have food and water for the weekend
Chicken door is secure
Paddock animals are safe and healthy
All shelter areas are accessible



Tools & Equipment

All tools are cleaned and stored properly
Watering cans and buckets stored upside down (prevent mosquito breeding)
No equipment left outside that should be stored
All sharp tools safely stored



Security & Safety

All gates and doors are secured
Shed and barn locked
No trip hazards left in pathways
Fire hazards cleared (wood chips, dry materials away from buildings)



Water & Utilities

No hoses or watering equipment left running
All taps turned off completely
Check for leaks or running water
Gutters and drains clear



General Farm Readiness

Work areas are tidy
Rubbish removed to appropriate bins
Farm log completed with any observations or issues
Any urgent issues reported to farm supervisor
Farm is ready for Monday!

title: Friday Farm Close-Down Checklist
text:
Weekend Considerations
Before you leave, consider:

Weather forecast: Does anything need extra securing for wind/rain?
Animal needs: Is weekend feed/water supply adequate?
Urgent issues: Has everything that needs immediate attention been reported?
Next week: Any special tasks or events to prepare for?

title: Friday Farm Close-Down Checklist
text:
Quick Mission Reference
If you notice something needs attention before the weekend:

Animals need care? ‚Üí Mission 1: Animal Care
Garden needs watering/weeding? ‚Üí Mission 2: Garden Maintenance
Trees need checking? ‚Üí Mission 3: Restoration
Want to make observations? ‚Üí Mission 4: Environmental Observation
Areas need tidying? ‚Üí Mission 5: Organisation


Well done, Farm Steward! Have a great weekend! üåæ
See you Monday!

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text: Google My Maps is a free tool for creating a farm plan, measuring distances and areas, and recording work done on the property. This guide helps you map our school farm features and plan future work.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text: Google My Maps is a free tool for creating a farm plan, measuring distances and areas, and recording work done on the property. This guide helps you map our school farm features and plan future work.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
Learning Goals

Create a digital farm map using layers.
Add points, lines, and areas with clear labels.
Measure distances and paddock areas accurately.
Export or print a clean map for your workbook.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
1. Getting Started

Go to https://www.google.co.nz/mymaps and sign in to your Google account. If you do not have an account, create one.
Click ‚ÄúCreate a new map‚Äù.
Click ‚ÄúUntitled map‚Äù to rename your map (for example, ‚ÄúKaikorai Valley College School Farm‚Äù).

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
2. Set Up Layers
Layers let you separate existing features from proposed work. You can turn layers on or off using the checkbox next to each layer.

Rename the first layer to Existing. Use this for current paddocks, dams, fences, buildings, and water points.
Click ‚ÄúAdd layer‚Äù and name it Proposed for future work such as new planting or fencing.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
3. Locate the Farm

Use the search bar to type in the school address, or zoom using the mouse wheel and the + / - buttons.
Click the arrow next to Base map and choose Satellite for a clear aerial view.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
4. Add Farm Features

A. Markers (Point Features)
Use markers for water tanks, sheds, gates, troughs, or trees.

Click the Marker icon under the search bar.
Click the exact spot on the map.
Give the marker a clear title, then save.




B. Lines (Fences, Tracks, Waterways)

Click the Line icon (right of the marker icon) and choose ‚ÄúAdd line or shape‚Äù.
Click along the path of the fence or creek.
Press Enter to finish the line and add a title.




C. Areas (Paddocks, Orchards, Bush)

Start the same way as a line.
Click around the boundary and then click the starting point to close the shape.
Add a title and save.



D. Edit or Delete Features
After saving a feature, a popup lets you edit color, line width, transparency, and description. You can also attach a photo or delete the feature using the trash bin icon.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
5. Measure Distances and Areas
The Measurement tool (ruler icon) helps you check distances or paddock sizes.

Click the ruler icon on the far right of the toolbar.
Click a starting point, then add points to measure a path.
For a polygon, close the shape to see both perimeter and area (in hectares).
Press Enter to finish a straight line measurement.
To stop measuring, click the hand icon or click anywhere on the screen.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
6. Export or Print Your Map

Option A: Print Map (Recommended)

Click the three vertical dots next to your map name.
Choose ‚ÄúPrint map‚Äù.
Pick paper size, orientation, and output type, then click Print.
A new PDF preview opens in your browser. Use the print icon to save as PDF or print.




Option B: Screenshot (Snipping Tool)
Windows

Open Snipping Tool from the Start menu search.
Click New, then drag to select the area.
Save the image and insert it into your workbook.

Mac

Press Shift + Command + 4.
Drag to select the area.
The screenshot saves to the desktop for inserting into your workbook.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
Map Checklist

Your map has a clear title.
Layers include Existing and Proposed.
Features are labeled with correct names.
At least one line and one area are mapped.
Measurements are used to check a distance or area.
Export is clean and readable.

title: Unit 1: Mapping the School Farm (3 weeks)
text:
Source and Further Help

Adapted from Beef + Lamb New Zealand User Guide (July 2021). PDF: resources/use-google-my-maps-map-your-farm.pdf. Site: https://www.beeflambnz.com
Extra help video: https://www.landcare.org.nz/resource-item/mapping
Google My Maps support: https://support.google.com/mymaps

title: Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
text: Your mission is to ensure the health and wellbeing of our farm animals. Complete these tasks to provide proper care for the chickens and paddock animals.

title: Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
text: Your mission is to ensure the health and wellbeing of our farm animals. Complete these tasks to provide proper care for the chickens and paddock animals.

title: Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
text:
The Chicken Visit



Chicken Area


Follow these steps carefully when visiting the hen house:

Move quietly and slowly into the hen house
Top up the water container using the fresh water at the barn (if needed)
Fill the feeder using the grain from the outside bin
Optional: Gently pat a chicken
Check for any signs of illness or injury
Observe chicken behavior - are they active and alert?

Safety Tips: - Move slowly to avoid startling the birds - Wash hands before and after handling - Report any unusual behavior to farm supervisor

title: Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
text:
Paddock Animal Check



Paddock Animals


Ensure paddock animals have clean water, fresh bedding, and food:

Scrub out the water trough and refill with clean water
Spread fresh wood shavings in the shelter bedding area
Place a scoop of nuts in the wooden trough for a snack
Check all animals are healthy and safe
Observe animal behavior and movement
Check fencing is secure

Important: - Always approach animals calmly - Never corner or chase animals - Report any injuries or concerns immediately

title: Mission 1: Animal Care & Observation
text:
Completion
Once all tasks are completed: - [ ] Return all equipment to proper storage - [ ] Record any observations in the farm log - [ ] Report any concerns to the farm supervisor
Mission Status: Complete! üêîüêë

title: Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
text: Your mission is to protect and maintain the farm‚Äôs restoration areas. This includes controlling invasive species and ensuring young trees establish successfully.

title: Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
text: Your mission is to protect and maintain the farm‚Äôs restoration areas. This includes controlling invasive species and ensuring young trees establish successfully.

title: Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
text:
Gorse Removal
Control invasive gorse to protect native plantings:

Gear up: Wear heavy-duty gloves and grab the loppers
Head to the hillside behind the poplars at the top of the farm
Cut gorse back to the base and pile it neatly for disposal
Work systematically across the designated area
Focus on gorse near young trees first
Stack cut material away from tree guards

Safety First: - Wear thick gloves - gorse is extremely spiky! - Use sharp, clean loppers for efficient cutting - Watch your footing on slopes - Take regular breaks - it‚Äôs hard work! - Never work alone in remote areas
Gorse Management Tips: - Cut as close to ground level as possible - Mark treated areas to track progress - Some regrowth is normal - repeat treatments needed - Pile cut material for later removal/burning

title: Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
text:
Young Tree Audit
Check on newly planted trees to ensure their survival:

Walk the farm perimeter and check all newly planted trees
Check: Are they still alive? Are the protective covers/guards secure?
Pull any grass or weeds growing inside the tree guards
Straighten any leaning stakes
Tighten any loose tree ties
Note any trees that need replacement

What to Look For: - Alive: Green leaves/buds, flexible branches, healthy bark - Dead/Dying: Brown leaves, brittle branches, damaged bark - Guards: Should be secure, upright, and properly ventilated - Weeds: Competition for water and nutrients - remove completely
Tree Care Tips: - Remove weeds within 50cm radius of each tree - Ensure guards don‚Äôt rub against tree bark - Tree ties should be secure but not too tight - Water young trees during dry periods if possible

title: Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
text:
Recording Observations
Help track restoration progress:

Count total number of trees checked
Record how many trees are thriving/struggling/dead
Note locations of problem areas
Take photos if significant changes observed
Report findings to farm supervisor

title: Mission 3: Restoration & Tree Health
text:
Completion
Once all tasks are completed: - [ ] Return all tools to proper storage - [ ] Record work completed in the farm log - [ ] Report any urgent issues (e.g., many dead trees) - [ ] Clean gloves and boots
Mission Status: Complete! üå≥

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text: Your mission is to maintain an organized, safe, and efficient farm workspace. A tidy farm is a safe farm and makes everyone‚Äôs work easier.

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text: Your mission is to maintain an organized, safe, and efficient farm workspace. A tidy farm is a safe farm and makes everyone‚Äôs work easier.

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text:
The Great Tidy-Up



Farm Barn



Barn & Shed Organisation:

Sweep the floors and clear any debris
Return all tools to their specific hooks or racks
Check that all tools are accounted for
Wipe down work surfaces
Organize shelves and storage areas
Stack bags and containers neatly
Remove any rubbish to appropriate bins

Organisation Principles: - A place for everything, everything in its place - Most-used items should be easiest to access - Heavy items stored low, light items stored high - Label storage areas clearly - Keep walkways clear and safe



Wood Pile Management:

Re-stack the wood pile behind the ‚Äòtoilet‚Äô area so it is neat and safe
Stack wood in stable rows
Keep wood off the ground (use pallets if available)
Arrange with bark side up to shed water
Remove any rotten or unsafe pieces
Ensure pile won‚Äôt topple over

Wood Stacking Tips: - Crisscross ends for stability - Lean slightly back against support - Leave air gaps for drying and ventilation - Stack away from buildings (fire safety)




Farm Shed




Pot Sort & Storage:

Head behind the barn to the pot storage area
Sort pots by size (small, medium, large)
Stack pots of same size inside each other
Remove any broken or damaged pots to recycling
Clean pots if needed (remove old soil/debris)
Store in a location that won‚Äôt block access
Keep different materials separate (plastic, terracotta, etc.)

Storage Guidelines: - Nest pots to save space - Store upside down to prevent water collection - Keep in shaded area to prevent UV damage - Maintain tidy stacks that won‚Äôt topple

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text:
Tool Audit
Proper tool maintenance extends their life and ensures safety:

Cleaning Protocol:

Clean all dirt off tools used today
Remove mud, sap, and plant material
Wipe metal parts with oily rag if rusty
Check wooden handles for splinters
Sharpen blades if necessary (ask supervisor)



Storage Protocol:

Ensure all watering cans and buckets are stored upside down (to prevent mosquito breeding)
Return all equipment to proper storage locations
Hang tools on designated hooks/racks
Coil hoses neatly
Store small tools in labeled containers
Place sharp tools safely (blades away from reach)

Tool Maintenance Tips: - Clean tools after each use - dried mud is harder to remove - Oil metal parts occasionally to prevent rust - Tighten loose handles before they break - Report damaged tools immediately - Don‚Äôt put tools away dirty or wet

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text:
Security Check
Before leaving the area:

Lock shed and secure gates
Close all doors and windows
Check nothing is left outside that shouldn‚Äôt be
Ensure no tools are laying around as trip hazards
Turn off any water taps
Check no electrical equipment left on
Do a final visual sweep of the area

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text:
Inventory Notes
Help maintain farm equipment:

Note any missing tools
Report any broken or damaged equipment
Suggest items that need replacing
Record any safety concerns
Update equipment log if maintained

title: Mission 5: Organisation & Inventory
text:
Completion
Once all tasks are completed: - [ ] Take a photo of tidy work area (optional) - [ ] Record completion in farm log - [ ] Report any issues to supervisor - [ ] Leave the farm better than you found it!
Mission Status: Complete! üßπüîß
